This patient has an initial episode of nonsevere
infection (CDI), which should be treated with oral vancomycin therapy (

). Risk factors for infection include exposure to antibiotic and chemotherapeutic agents, older age, presence of inflammatory bowel disease, gastrointestinal surgery, and (possibly) gastric acid suppression with proton pump inhibitors. Antibiotic stewardship is paramount in reducing incidence of infection, and hand washing with soap and water is the gold standard for infection control; alcohol-based gels do not eliminate spores. Disease severity (nonsevere, severe, and fulminant) and initial or recurrent presentation guide treatment selection. Nonsevere CDI is defined by a leukocyte count of less than 15,000/µL (15 × 10

/L) and a serum creatinine level of less than 1.5 mg/dL (133 µmol/L). The 2021 Infectious Diseases Society of America and Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America clinical practice guideline for CDI suggests either oral fidaxomicin (preferred) or oral vancomycin (alternative) for treatment of an initial episode of nonsevere or severe disease. If these agents are unavailable or intolerable, oral metronidazole (

Oral vancomycin (by mouth or nasogastric tube) and intravenous metronidazole (

) is recommended for fulminant CDI. Fulminant CDI is associated with hypotension, shock, ileus, or megacolon. If an ileus is present, rectal instillation of vancomycin should be considered. Patients with fulminant disease warrant surgical evaluation.
